sen.j: 徳川 和子（とくがわ まさこ、慶長12年10月4日（1607年11月23日） - 延宝6年6月15日（1678年8月2日））は、徳川秀忠の娘（五女）で、後水尾天皇の中宮。
sen.e: Masako TOKUGAWA (November 23rd, 1607 - August 2nd, 1678) was a daughter of Hidetada TOKUGAWA (the fifth daughter) and Emperor Gomizunoo's Chugu. (second consort of an Emperor)
Masako TOKUGAWA (November 23rd, 1607 - August 2nd, 1678) was the 5th daughter of Hidetada TOKUGAWA and Emperor Gomizunoo's Chugu. (second consort of an Emperor)
Masako TOKUGAWA (November 23, 1607 - August 2, 1678) was the 5th daughter of Hidetada TOKUGAWA and Emperor Gomizunoo's Chugu (second consort of an Emperor).
sen.cmt: 日付表記を修正ピリオドの位置移動

sen.j: 明正天皇の生母。
sen.e: Emperor Meisho's birth mother.
Emperor Meisho's birth mother.
Emperor Meisho's birth mother.

sen.j: 慶長12年（1607年）10月4日、徳川家康より将軍職を譲られた徳川秀忠と正室崇源院夫妻の間に7番目の子（5女）として誕生する。
sen.e: After Ieyasu TOKUGAWA passed his Shogun position to Hidetada TOKUGAWA, Kazuko was born as seventh child (fifth daughter) between Hidetada and his wife, Sugen in on October 4th, 1607.
After Ieyasu TOKUGAWA passed his position of Shogun to Hidetada TOKUGAWA, Kazuko was born as seventh child (fifth daughter) between Hidetada and his wife, Sugen in on October 4th, 1607.
After Ieyasu TOKUGAWA passed his position of Shogun to Hidetada TOKUGAWA, Kazuko was born as seventh child (fifth daughter) between Hidetada and his wife, Sugen in on November 23, 1607.

sen.j: 最初の名は松姫（まつひめ）。
sen.e: Initially she was named Matsuhime.
Initially she was named Matsuhime.
Initially she was named Matsuhime.

sen.j: 慶長17年（1612年）には後水尾天皇が即位するが、大御所家康は和子の入内を申し入れ、慶長19年（1614年）4月に入内宣旨が出される。
sen.e: After Emperor Gomizunoo enthroned, the Lord Ieyasu asked the Imperial Palace of Kazuko's Imperial Consort's bridal entry into court in 1612, he received an imperial letter of acceptance in April 1614.

After Emperor Gomizunoo was enthroned, Lord Ieyasu asked the Imperial Palace, Kazuko's Imperial Consort's, for bridal entry into court in 1612, he received an imperial letter of acceptance in April 1614.

After Emperor Gomizunoo was enthroned, Lord Ieyasu asked the Imperial Palace, Kazuko's Imperial Consort's, for bridal entry into court in 1612, he received an imperial letter of acceptance in May 1614.

sen.j: 入内は豊臣家との大坂の陣や元和2年（1616年）の大御所家康の死去、後陽成天皇の死去などが続いたため延期された。
sen.e: The Actual entry into the Palace was postponed due to the Siege of Osaka Castle of Toyotomi family, or Ieyasu's death (1616) and Emperor Goyozei's death and so on.
The Actual entry into the Palace was postponed due to the Siege of Toyotomi family's Osaka Castle, Ieyasu's death (1616) and Emperor Goyozei's death, etc..
The actual entry into the Palace was postponed due to the Siege of Toyotomi family's Osaka Castle, Ieyasu's death (1616) and Emperor Goyozei's death, etc..

sen.j: 元和4年（1618年）には女御御殿の造営が開始されるが、後水尾天皇の寵愛する女官四辻与津子（お与津御寮人）が皇子賀茂宮を出産していたことが判明すると入内は問題視される。
sen.e: In 1618 the construction work of Nyogo Palace was started, however, after it was found out Emperor Gomizunoo's favorite lady, a court lady, Yotsuko YOTSUTSUJI (Oyotsu oryonin) gave a birth to Prince Kamo no Miya, the arrangement of Kazuko's entry into the court became complicated.
sen.cmt: お与津御寮人→読み方確認できず
sen.e: In 1618 construction work of the Nyogo Palace was started, however, after it was found out Emperor Gomizunoo's favorite lady, a court lady, Yotsuko YOTSUTSUJI (Oyotsu oryonin) gave birth to Prince Kamo no Miya, the arrangement for Kazuko's entry into the court became complicated.

In 1618 construction work of the Nyogo Palace was started, however, after it was found out Emperor Gomizunoo's favorite lady, a court lady, Yotsuko YOTSUTSUJI (Oyotsu oryonin) gave birth to Prince Kamo no Miya, the arrangement for Kazuko's entry into the court became complicated.

sen.j: 翌元和5年には秀忠自身が上洛して参内し、与津子の兄弟である四辻季継・高倉嗣良を含む近臣らを配流し、与津子と所生の皇女文智女王らを宮中より追放することなどで合意した（およつ一件、お与津御寮人事件）。
sen.e: On the following year, Genwa (Genna) 5, Hidetada came to the Palace, and the issue was agreed by sentencing some close aides including Yotsuko's brothers, Suetsugu YOTSUTSUJI and Tsuguyoshi TAKAKURA to deportation, and expelling Yotsuko and Princess Bunchi out of the Imperial Palace. (The Oyotsu incident, The Oyotsu oryonin incident)
sen.cmt: およつ一件、お与津御寮人事件→定訳不明
sen.e: IN the following year, Genwa (Genna) 5, Hidetada came to the Palace, and the issue was resolved by sentencing some close aides including Yotsuko's brothers, Suetsugu YOTSUTSUJI and Tsuguyoshi TAKAKURA to banishment, and expelling Yotsuko and Princess Bunchi from the Imperial Palace. (The Oyotsu incident, The Oyotsu oryonin incident)

In the following year, in 1619, Hidetada came to the Palace, and the issue was resolved by sentencing some close aides including Yotsuko's brothers, Suetsugu YOTSUTSUJI and Tsuguyoshi TAKAKURA to banishment, and expelling Yotsuko and Princess Bunchi from the Imperial Palace. (The Oyotsu incident, The Oyotsu oryonin incident)

sen.j: 元和6年（1620年）6月18日に後水尾天皇の女御として入内する。
sen.e: Kazuko made an Imperial Consort's bridal entry into court on June 18th, 1620.
Kazuko made the Imperial Consort's bridal entry into court on June 18th, 1620.
Kazuko made the Imperial Consort's bridal entry as an Emperor Gomizunoo's nyogo (a high-ranking lady in the court (a consort of an emperor)) into court on July 17, 1620.
sen.cmt: 日付表記を修正as an Emperor Gomizunoo's nyogo (a high-ranking lady in the court (a consort of an emperor))補足June 18→July 17

sen.j: このときは二条城から盛大な行列を伴い、『東福門院入内図屏風』にはその様子が描かれている。
sen.e: There was a huge parade from the Nijo-jo Castle for this celebration, and it was painted in "Tofukumon in painting on a folding screen of Kazuko's Imperial Consort's bridal entry into court".
There was a huge parade from the Nijo-jo Castle for this celebration, and it was painted as "Tofukumon in a painting on a folding screen of Kazuko's Imperial Consort's bridal entry into court".
There was a huge parade from the Nijo-jo Castle for this celebration, and it was painted as "Tofukumon in a painting on a folding screen of Kazuko's Imperial Consort's bridal entry into court."

sen.j: 元和9年（1623年）には懐妊し、同年6月には秀忠と嫡男徳川家光が将軍宣下のため上洛し、禁裏御領一万石を寄進される。
sen.e: In 1623 she was pregnant, in June, Hidetada and the eldest son, Iemitsu TOKUGAWA came to the Palace for Shogun senge (the ceremony to appoint Seii Taishogun (literally "great general who subdues the Barbarians")), then they received ten thousand koku land belongs to the Imperial Palace.
sen.cmt: 禁裏御領一万石→定訳不明
sen.e: In 1623 she was pregnant, in June, Hidetada and the eldest son, Iemitsu TOKUGAWA came to the Palace for Shogun senge (ceremony to appoint Seii Taishogun (literally "great general who subdues the Barbarians")), then they received ten thousand koku land belonging to the Imperial Palace.

In 1623 she was pregnant, in June, Hidetada and the eldest son, Iemitsu TOKUGAWA came to the Palace for Shogun senge (ceremony to appoint Seii Taishogun (literally "great general who subdues the barbarians")), then they received ten thousand koku land belonging to the Imperial Palace.

sen.j: 同年11月19日には女一宮興子内親王（後の明正天皇）が誕生する。
sen.e: The First Princess, Imperial Princess Okiko (later called Emperor Meisho) was born on November 19th in the same year.
The First Princess, Imperial Princess Okiko (later called Empress Meisho) was born on November 19th in the same year.
The First Princess, Imperial Princess Okiko (later called Empress Meisho) was born on January 9, 1624.
sen.cmt: スペース削除日付表記を修正November 19 in the same year→January 9, 1624

sen.j: 翌寛永元年には冊立され中宮となり、翌寛永2年9月には女二宮が誕生する。
sen.e: On the following year of Kanei 1, she was officially appointed as Chugu (second consort of an emperor), in September Kanei 2, the second Princess was born.
In the following year of Kanei 1, she was officially appointed as Chugu (second consort of an emperor), in September Kanei 2, the second Princess was born.
In the following year of 1624, she was officially appointed as Chugu (second consort of an emperor), in October 1625, the second Princess was born.

sen.j: 翌寛永3年には秀忠・家光が上洛し後水尾天皇の二条城行幸が行われ、和子は同年11月13日には高仁親王を出産している（早世）。
sen.e: In Kanei 3, Hidetada and Iemitsu came to Kyoto and Emperor Gomizunoo visited the Nijo-jo Castle, Kazuko gave a birth to Imperial Prince Sukehito on November 13th in the same year. (died young)
In Kanei 3, Hidetada and Iemitsu came to Kyoto and Emperor Gomizunoo visited the Nijo-jo Castle, Kazuko gave birth to Imperial Prince Sukehito on November 13th in the same year. (died young)
In 1626, Hidetada and Iemitsu came to Kyoto and Emperor Gomizunoo visited the Nijo-jo Castle, Kazuko gave birth to Imperial Prince Sukehito on December 31 in the same year (died young).
sen.cmt: Kanei 3→1626日付表記を修正ピリオドの位置November 13 →December 31

sen.j: 寛永6年（1627年）には朝幕間で紫衣事件が発生し、同年10月8日に後水尾天皇は突然譲位し、女一宮に内親王宣下が下される。
sen.e: There was the Shie Incident happened between the Imperial Palace and the Tokugawa shogunate, on October 8th in the same year, Emperor Mizunoo suddenly succeeded to the throne, and the first Princess was officially appointed as an Imperial Princess.

The Shie Incident happened between the Imperial Palace and the Tokugawa shogunate, on October 8th of the same year, Emperor Mizunoo suddenly succeeded to the throne, and the first Princess was officially appointed as an Imperial Princess.

In 1629 the Shie Incident happened between the Imperial Palace and the Tokugawa shogunate, on November 22 of the same year, Emperor Mizunoo suddenly succeeded to the throne, and the first Princess was officially appointed as an Imperial Princess.

sen.j: 同年11月9日には院号を東福門院（とうふくもんいん）と称する。
sen.e: On November 9th, 1627, Kazuko was given the in go title of Tofukumon in.
On November 9th, 1627, Kazuko was given the in go title of Tofukumon in.
On December 23, 1629, Kazuko was given the in go title of Tofukumon in.

sen.j: 翌寛永7年（1630年）9月12日、女一宮は即位し、明正天皇となる。
sen.e: On September 12th, 1630, the first Princess succeeded to the throne and became Emperor Meisho.
On September 12th, 1630, the first Princess succeeded to the throne and became Empress Meisho.
On October 17, 1630, the first Princess succeeded to the throne and became Empress Meisho.

sen.j: 寛永11年(1634年）には新将軍となった兄の家光が上洛し、姪にあたる明正天皇に拝謁し東福門院の御所も訪れている。
sen.e: In 1634, Kazuko's older brother, Iemitsu who became new Shogun came to Kyoto to see his niece, Emperor Meisho and visited the Palace of Tofukumon in.
In 1634, Kazuko's older brother, Iemitsu, who became new Shogun, came to Kyoto to see his niece, Empress Meisho, and visited the Palace of Tofukumon in.
In 1634, Kazuko's older brother, Iemitsu, who became new Shogun, came to Kyoto to see his niece, Empress Meisho, and visited the Palace of Tofukumon in.
On June 15th, 1678, Kazuko died.
On June 15th, 1678, Kazuko died.
On August 2, 1678, Kazuko died.

tit.cmt: A person→Personal Profileに変更しました。

sen.j: 家康は徳川家を天皇外戚とするべく皇子誕生の期待を持って和子を宮中に送り込んだ意図があったと考えられているが、出生した2皇子はすべて早世している。
sen.e: It is said Ieyasu sent his daughter, Kazuko to the Imperial Palace since he wished Kazuko to give birth to the Prince for Tokugawa family to become maternal relative to the Emperor, however two Princes who were born both died young.

It is said that Ieyasu sent his daughter, Kazuko to the Imperial Palace because he wished Kazuko to give birth to a Prince for the Tokugawa family to become maternal relatives of the Emperor, however both Princes who were born died young.

It is said that Ieyasu sent his daughter, Kazuko to the Imperial Palace because he wished Kazuko to give birth to a Prince for the Tokugawa family to become maternal relatives of the Emperor, however both Princes who were born died young.

sen.j: そのため、夫と別の女性との間に生まれた後光明天皇を養子として実娘・明正天皇の後継者とし、夫と徳川家双方の面目を立てた。
sen.e: Therefore Emperor Gokomyo who was born between the Emperor and other woman was adopted to succeed to the throne after Kazuko's daughter, Emperor Meisho, this way, Kazuko was able to preserve both the Emperor's and Tokugawa family's honor.

Therefore Emperor Gokomyo who was born between the Emperor and aother woman was adopted to succeed to the throne after Kazuko's daughter, Emperor Meisho, this way, Kazuko was able to preserve both the Emperor's and the Tokugawa family's honor.

Therefore Emperor Gokomyo who was born between the Emperor and aother woman was adopted to succeed to the throne after Kazuko's daughter, Emperor Meisho, this way, Kazuko was able to preserve both the Emperor's and the Tokugawa family's honor.

sen.j: その他、気が強い夫・後水尾天皇と天皇家を押さえつけようとする幕府の間を取り持つことに奔走する気苦労の多い生涯であった。
sen.e: She always had her worries in her life since she tried hard to make soothe relationship between her dominant husband, Emperor Gomizunoo, and the Tokugawa shogunate, who kept on putting pressure on to the Imperial family.

She always had her worries in her life, but she tried hard to soothe the relationship between her dominant husband, Emperor Gomizunoo, and the Tokugawa shogunate, who kept pressuring the Imperial family.

She always had her worries in her life, but she tried hard to soothe the relationship between her dominant husband, Emperor Gomizunoo, and the Tokugawa shogunate, who kept pressuring the Imperial family.

sen.j: 修学院離宮を建てた費用の大半が和子の要請により幕府から捻出させた物とされる。
sen.e: It is said most of the finances to build the Shugakuin Imperial Villa came from the Tokugawa Shogunate as Kazuko requested it.
It is said most of the finances to build the Shugakuin Imperial Villa came from the Tokugawa Shogunate as Kazuko requested.
It is said most of the finances to build the Shugakuin Imperial Villa came from the Tokugawa Shogunate as Kazuko requested.

sen.j: また、後光明天皇の崩御直後にその弟の後西天皇の即位を渋る（後西天皇が仙台藩伊達綱宗の従兄弟であったため）幕府を説得して即位を実現させたのも彼女の尽力によるとされる。
sen.e: She also persuaded Tokugawa shogunate who refused to accept Emperor Gosai's enthronement immediately after his older brother, Emperor Gokomyo died. (this was due to Emperor Gosai being a second cousin of Tsunamune DATE of the Sendai domain.)

She also persuaded the Tokugawa shogunate, who refused to accept Emperor Gosai's enthronement immediately after his older brother, Emperor Gokomyo died. (due to Emperor Gosai being a second cousin of Tsunamune DATE of the Sendai domain.)

She also persuaded the Tokugawa shogunate, who refused to accept Emperor Gosai's enthronement immediately after his older brother, Emperor Gokomyo died. (due to Emperor Gosai being a second cousin of Tsunamune DATE of the Sendai Domain.)

sen.j: 夫・後水尾天皇は後に寛永文化といわれる様々な文芸芸術の振興に尽くしたことで知られるが、妻の和子自身もかなりのセンスの持ち主であった。
sen.e: Her husband, Emperor Gomizunoo was known he contributed to promote various arts of Kanei culture, the wife Kazuko also had quite a talent in arts.
Her husband, Emperor Gomizunoo was known for his contributions to promote various arts of Kanei culture, his wifem Kazuko, also had quite a talent in the arts.
Her husband, Emperor Gomizunoo was known for his contributions to promote various arts of Kanei culture, his wife Kazuko, also had quite a talent in the arts.

sen.j: 宮中に小袖を着用する習慣を持ち込んだのは和子といわれ、尾形光琳・尾形乾山兄弟の実家である雁金屋を取り立てたとされる。
sen.e: It is said it was Kazuko who introduced a custom to wear Kosode (Kimono with short sleeves) into the Imperial Palace, she preferred to use Karigane ya which was the house where Korin and Kenzan OGATA brothers were born.

It is said it was Kazuko who introduced the custom to wear Kosode (Kimono with short sleeves) into the Imperial Palace, she preferred to use Karigane ya which was the house where the Korin and Kenzan OGATA brothers were born.

It is said it was Kazuko who introduced the custom to wear Kosode (Kimono with short sleeves) into the Imperial Palace, she preferred to use Karigane ya which was the house where the Korin and Kenzan OGATA brothers were born.

sen.j: 和子の注文した小袖のデザインは後に年号から“寛文小袖”と言われるようになった。
sen.e: The particular Kosode design which Kazuko used to order was called "Kanbun Kosode", the name came from the era.
The particular Kosode design which Kazuko used to order was called "Kanbun Kosode," the name was derived from the era.
The particular Kosode design which Kazuko used to order was called "Kanbun Kosode," the name was derived from the era.

sen.j: また、手先が非常に器用な女性であり、特に押絵を得意とした。
sen.e: She was also clever with her hands, especially good at making a raised cloth pictures.
She was also clever with her hands, especially good at making raised cloth pictures.
sen.cmt: grammar (I wonder if embroidery is the correct term for "raised cloth pictures?)
sen.e: She was also clever with her hands, especially good at making a raised cloth pictures.
sen.cmt: 最初の翻訳の方が適切です。I agree with the above. Embroidery is not quite the same thing. Although "raised cloth picture" doesn't get a huge number of hits on Google, it gets a reasonable amount and they seem to be related to the images you see if you do a Google Images search for "押絵".

sen.j: 現在日本現存最古の押絵は和子の作成の物と言われる。
sen.e: It is said the oldest, existing raised cloth picture was made by Kazuko.
It is said that the oldest, existing raised cloth picture was made by Kazuko.
It is said that the oldest, existing raised cloth picture was made by Kazuko.

sen.j: また、京の文化人にとっては和子の押絵を拝領されることは一種のステータスであり、現在千家では和子作の押絵を多数所蔵しているという。
sen.e: It was a kind of fashion to have Kazuko's pictures for highly-educated people in Kyoto, the current Sen Family have many pictures of Kazuko's.
It was a kind of fashion to have Kazuko's pictures for highly-educated people in Kyoto, the present day Sen Family has many pictures done by Kazuko.
It was a kind of fashion to have Kazuko's pictures for highly-educated people in Kyoto, the present day Sen Family has many pictures done by Kazuko.
